I will say that books of this type and authors of this type (no insult intended) and programs with "TV Doctors" like Doctor Oz can be very appealing to laypersons.  Put medical information in a "catchy format" that can be consumed in 30 seconds or less and you have the makings of a hit tv program or best selling book.  Flip comments sell books. And, they are books that I don't read...mainly because I resent someone / anyone cashing in on my disease....and, yes, I am aware that these psuedo-doctors are doing us a service...it's just not something that I appreciate. There has been speculation about lymphadema causes v. not causes in recent number of years. I think it is certainly a worthy topic of discussion. tl
Posts.Title: Susan Love proclaims no need for lymphedema risk reductions kira TammyLou

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2009 03:48AM - edited Nov 10, 2009 03:50AM by TammyLou Oh, yea...LittleC...stage 3C = me, too. Somehow, I don't think my tombstone is going to read, "She was overtreated." In all cases, the benefits of treatment must outweigh the risk. Remarkably, I have lived long enough to exprerience some of the "late" side effects of cancer treatment.  While I was taking cancer treatment, I never imagined that to be possible...that I would live long enough to regret any treatment "choice." Essentially, in the realm of advanced cancer, we are the people who are presented with the fewest options.  We don't do the, "Do you want to take radiation?" We don't "decide" whether we will do chemo, when or how much. There is no grey area.  There are no gray areas either.  :) For us, it is basically do or die...or do and die. I did. I have lived. That is all. tl

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2010 03:47PM TammyLou wrote: Generally, people with breast cancer receive a limited dose.  (divided by 30 or so days...given in fractions /doses.)  [I was very angry when I received my rads...people used the word, "breeze."]  IF the cancer is advanced....those patients (like me) will recieve a significantly higher dose...divided in fractions.  (And I would not use the word "breeze.") This would be the difference between having one shot of tequila versus drinking the entire bottle in one sitting.  That being said, the majority (80%?)  of breast cancer patients have Stage 1/2 cancers and they normally do not experience "terrible" side effects. tl

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2009 08:25PM - edited Oct 24, 2009 08:26PM by TammyLou My best understanding is that you need to have a nice flat chest wall to radiate. I don't know of anyone (ever) with IBC who was offered immediate reconstruction. With advanced disease, the PRIORITY for treatment is the cancer. Technically, we must be released by the oncologist to the plastic surgeon for reconstruction. tl P.S.  I think that there's a specific IBC forum on this website.  You may want to ask there.

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2009 10:28PM TammyLou wrote: Taxotere, THEN FEC. Ask for Emend...it's expensive, but probably worth it.  Stock up on Pepcid A/C. FEC is an anthracycline, like AC...similar side effects. Tammy Lou
Posts.Title: Starting FEC-T tomorrow.... KerryMac pip57

Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2009 02:32PM - edited Jul 23, 2009 02:33PM by TammyLou (Not what I did...but, mainly because I wanted to prevent developing a "new" cancer because I am high risk.  Cancer was inoperable at diagnosis.  After neoadjuvant chemo, I chose bi-lateral mastectomies and I had extensive chest wall radiation.) One of the main reasons to try neoadjuvant chemo is that it may allow some women to preserve their breast tissue. Currently, there is no data to support the idea that neoadjuvant chemo (as opposed to chemo after surgery) improves survival...it can shrink the cancer and make it easier to remove, and it may allow for breast conservation. SO,  if you prefer lumpectomy (and rads), then that is a reasonable option. Tammy Lou
Posts.Title: The road less traveled carolesue Gayleebug

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2009 09:13AM TammyLou wrote: I think it depends on your situation.  If you are young, you may have 40% risk of bc in "good" breast over your lifetime.  This risk can be reduced by hormone blockers if the cancer you have had happened to be ER+. My best understanding is that people who have had breast cancer are at higher risk of having more breast cancer and other (especially "female" type) cancers. This is a difficult area.  Breast cancer is / can be both a systemic and a local disease. Generally, a local recurrance is a harbinger of more disease. Bad joo joo....more likely to accompany distant disease than other / previous cancer. Of course, no one actually knows the correct answer.  Speaking personally, I would be disinclined to keep a breast as a "diagnostic" tool.  There is no evidence that having a boobie prevents distant mets.  I'd sooner read tea leaves. tl

Posts.Content: Nov 18, 2009 08:42AM - edited Nov 18, 2009 08:45AM by TammyLou I agree with the Danish.  It only hurts when my heart beats. tl P.S.  Yes, jimbo.  It is "normal."  At any given time, it would be "logical" to me that I have mets somewhere...and, yet, I am all clear, and have been for the last 5 years.  It has gotten better, but I am in low level chronic pain that is "helped" by the 15mg Mobic that I take daily plus extra strength tylenol as needed (usually at least one dose in a given day.)  When I do something that aggravates it...takes weeks to get back to the low level (of chronic pain.) Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2009 10:17AM TammyLou wrote: Mary, even with a TRAM or DIEP, there is some original skin salvaged in the breast area to sew the transplanted skin to. Some of that is probably radiated skin and can be tighter than the non-radiated side. alaskalady, I'm seeing a PS on 9/15 about a delayed bilateral DIEP. When recon is done after radiation, the best results are with an autologous transfers (TRAM flaps, DIEP flaps, etc). If they try to do expanders and implant after radiaition, the skin doesn't always stretch well enough on the radiated side, and there tends to be more complications (such as Mary's cellulitis or capsular contraction). Radiated skin has had some changes on the molecular level and just doesn't react the same as non-radiated skin. " That is also my best understanding. MS Free TRAMS for me. tl

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2009 11:29AM - edited Nov 8, 2009 11:32AM by TammyLou I sure would want a second opinion on that. There is a WAY big difference between clinical response and what is ACTUAL.  (Take it from the women who had all clean imaging...yet, still had cancer present when they were opened up.) Stage 3C for me...RADS (in 6 fields with 2 sets of boosts) followed pathologically complete response (NO cancer present after chemo determined by surgical excision). If I was you, chickie...I would want a well-known major cancer treatment center to confirm the integrity of that "plan"...unless you are 100 years old and/or have some kind of other major health problem (cardiac or diabetes) that may cause "issues" with tolerating rads. tl

In January 2005, I was diagnosed with Stage 3C Breast Cancer, with fixed matted lymph nodes wrapped around my chest wall. Posts.Title: link between bras and breast cancer MayRunner RunswithScissors

Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2009 08:35PM TammyLou wrote: My best understanding is that certain cancers have the ability to circulate through the bloodstream and survive/build colonies in organs and bones....and others, less so. Having lymph node involvement is often interpreted as a sign that the cancer has the ability to circulate and grow in organs/bones. However, that is only a sign.  Rarely, there are breast cancers that don't "like" lymph nodes...and they don't inhabit them.,,they prefer and inhabit organs and bones immediately, regardless of primary cancer size. Most commonly, lymph node positive cancers are associated with more aggressive disease and small breast tumors without involvement are associated with less aggressive. The critical issue is that cancer doesn't always follow the rules. tl
Posts.Title: I don't get it Pure keno41

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2009 09:01AM TammyLou wrote: Having ENDURED breast cancer, and I am specifically choosing that word, I can tell you, sir...that the article is funny to a certain audience in a certain context.  It is funny to many of the people who have endured. It is an example of black humor. We are dying.  Some of us are dying.  Some of us are spectacularly aware of our mortality...and somehow, we have to get through daily life functions.  We cry.  We laugh at jokes that would be inappropriate in another context.  Finding humor in our own tragic situation(s) may not be pleasing to people who are not part of this culture...but, it is a way of coping. Illiterate, ill-informed people make tremendous efforts to "simplify" breast cancer for us.   If you had any idea of the number of times that well-meaning individuals approached me with similar sorts of ideas...in very serious circumstances.   Apparently, what I really need to do is "keep a positive attitude."  Wear my warrior t-shirt with pride...like that is REALLY going to change my prognosis. There is alot of pressure on cancer patients to be "perky."  The power of repetition can cause certain issues to be perceived as humorous. As a breast cancer patient, I was the target (and I still am) of many suggestions. My head is leaning on the cool porcelain and I have been puking my guts out for 12 hours.  This is probably not a good time for a "pep talk" on how I need to "keep a positive attitude."  You might be met with a less than favorable response. Timing is everything.  Right now, you may feel traumatized by your wife's recent diagnosis...and this "humor" is inappropriate.  Frankly, in the light of my experiences, it is hilarious. The walking wounded. tl

Posts.Title: Anyone out there with more than 10 nodes positive? TammytrustsGod margyc

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2009 02:58PM - edited Oct 29, 2009 02:59PM by TammyLou I strongly wanted recon, and I persisted and I got it...and, it was the right choice for me. HOWEVER, I spent a couple of years boobless. I now have 2 flap reconstructions.  And, I can tell you that there is little difference between "strap on" boobies and my flaps. The key difference is that I don't have to strap them on.  Just call me, "Mrs. Doubtfire." (total lack of feeling...nerves are cut during mastectomy). In other words, I have some good place holders that keep my shirt up...and I'm "happy" with them, but they are nothing like real boobies.  They look like boobies, but with a bra on, there's little external difference (prosthetics vs recon.) As far as naked goes, it's less traumatic...but, the scars are reminders.  Anybody who sees me naked knows something bad happened here.  Skin-sparing tends to produce better outcomes.  Time fades scars, but they are still prominent.  Naked, I feel like I have to "explain" the scars. It's hot as hades in South Mississippi and it is convenient having reconstructions...in the event that I'm going "commando"...I've gotten used to my flaps and in clothing, I am less self-conscious about them. It's kind of like having false teeth.  I know they're not "real"...the big difference to me...recon versus no recon is that I don't have to strap on my fake boobs...when I wake up in the morning, they're already on. I have formed an impression that immediate recon is less traumatic...but it will still be traumatic, because this will be a drastic body change.  Sort of like having a surrogate stuffed animal...it helps, but it isn't what you're used to.  tl P.S.  I was age 40 at diagnosis...45 grand years old now!  :)

Posts.Title: Breast Cancer Girl Shanagirl Shanagirl

Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2009 08:33PM TammyLou wrote: Cool Breeze...I think I'd take that 30th surgery date.  2 weeks is not a long time...and I don't think you could (start over) and get in any faster. How old are you? It is possible that there are prognostic factors related to risk of recurrance (in the contralateral) and lymph node spread issues that are causing the doctors to recommend surgery first. Chemo before surgery is often offered to Stage 3 patients...this is mainly to make the cancer easier to remove (or allow for breast conservation.) It is possible that with the cancer close to the chest wall, they want to do surgical excision, rather than chemo first.  This also allows for more exact staging.  (Under the microscope is more "absolute" than scans / imaging.)  tl
Posts.Title: "Are you waiting for me to die, or what?" CoolBreeze lexislove

Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2009 01:26PM TammyLou wrote: Right here!  :)  Alive and kicking!  Diagnosed in January 2005 with Stage 3C Invasive Ductal Carcinoma...fixed, matted lymph nodes in excess of 8cm. It took 3 months to stage me.  Cancer not visible in breast through "normal" imaging methods.  Diagnosis was made by removal and analysis of a 3cm lymph node clump in early January 2005. It is very scary for the patient when the doctors do the "deer in the headlights" thing. My local doctors did the "deer in the headlights" thing.  "We've never seen anything like this...we've called all over the country."  I went to a major cancer treatment center in my region.  (More tests, more scans, more "hmmmms") I began chemotherapy in April 2005.  4 rounds of Taxotere.  4 rounds of FEC.  52 weeks concurrent Herceptin.  Radiation in 6 fields with 2 sets of boosts. I am still alive. Currently, no cancer. tl
Posts.Title: "Are you waiting for me to die, or what?" CoolBreeze lexislove

(chemo first, then surgery) Walked around with fixed, matted lymph nodes stuck to my chest wall for 10-12 weeks while the doctors figured out what to do (or what not to do.) Cancer inoperable at diagnosis.  If waiting made it worse, I don't know about it...fortunately, I responded well to treatment. tl
Posts.Title: "Are you waiting for me to die, or what?" CoolBreeze lexislove

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2010 11:56AM TammyLou wrote: I think this can be very confusing. The most probable case is that you have fibrocystic breasts...very common. This is a "benign" condition (not breast cancer) and it is common for the lumps to come and go...and sometimes, relates to menstral cycle. The only way that I know of to positively diagnose breast cancer is to biopsy.  So, when something suspicious is seen on imaging or felt, the doctor may order biopsy to rule out breast cancer. It is reasonable to believe that the breast specialist would be able (by feel) to identify what's a lump and what may be other structures in your chest wall (like underlying muscle). It is unlikely that if there is nothing on imaging and nothing on palpation that the doctor would be willing to order a biopsy. (I have no medical training).  I would personally be inclined to do my regular doctor visits (gyn etc.) and have the routine scans that my doctor recommends. The overwhelming likelihood is that if you have had this lump for 4 years and nothing dramatic has happened, (it hasn't grown, etc.), it probably is not breast cancer. People, in general, have all sorts of structures in their bodies that come and go that scientists cannot really explain.  I've had a few myself that have popped up on scan (and it is scary!). ...so I can dig it. tl
